channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #93 - DBIx::Class - the 'x' Now Stands for Xtremely Fast
item.description:
Hi

this issue was put together by Yanick Champoux, I just added a few extra items. (Thanks Yanick!) If you follow my other Perl-related publication, the Perl Maven site, you saw that in the last two weeks I started to conduct interviews with Perl developers. Do you find these interviews interesting? What else would you like to ask? Who else would you like to see being interviewed? Let me know!

See you next week!

item.title: state51 is hiring Perl Developers to work with Music and Metadata
item.description:
Based in London, state51 makes a platform to manage music and metadata. Working with distributors, indie and major labels we have delivered millions of tracks to hundreds of music services. The developer team is small and in control of its own tools (Catalyst, Moose, Git, Puppet, Jenkins) and environment.

Full job posting here

item.title: Perl DBIx::Class - An Awesome ORM Now With Super Speed!
item.description: A new release of DBIx::Class is out. Amongst the new stuff that it brings:performance improvements. How much performance improvements? According to some of the benchmarks, it is 20 very sweet percents faster than the previous release.

item.title: Outreach Program for Women
item.description: Deadline for application is May 8th. Hurry!

item.title: Moose objects and roles
item.description: Steve Cook writes a nice primer to the wonderful world of Moose (and roles,natch).

item.title: All about Perl 6 - interview of Flavio Glock
item.description: Nikos Vaggalis interviews Flavio Glock about Perlito, the compiler collection that implements a subset of Perl 5 and Perl 6.

item.title: Web Frameworks Round 4
item.description: A benchmark of web frameworks in many languages. Perl being represented by Dancer, Kelp and Mojolicious.

item.title: Vintage Perl Articles by Dave Cross
item.description: Dave Cross's blog has a new 'article' section where he has put the articles that he wrote for perl.com... 10 years ago. Will you dare boarding this Nostalgia Ride?

item.title: SawyerX Interview with Pragmatic Perl in English
item.description: SawyerX was interviewed by the Russian e-magazine Pragmatic Perl. At last, an English version is now offered for the Cyrillic-challenged amongst us.

item.title: Pinto Tutorial in 8 languages
item.description: Want to learn all about Pinto, but can't read English? You're in luck, its tutorial is now translated in 8 other langu-- hey, wait a second here, how come you can read this, then?

item.title: /usr/local/bin rant
item.description: Vyacheslav Matyukhin gets bitten by the pesky peculiarities of PATH across platforms.

item.title: Perl Catalyst and the Crisis of Asynchronicity
item.description: Ah yes. Asynchronicity. Six syllables fit so send shivers down many a developer's spine. John Napiorkowski explains how much fun the Catalyst team is having with it nowadays, and ask for users' input to help trace the path forward.

item.title: The CPAN Testers game
item.description: One of the CPAN's strengths is its army of testers, relentlessly testing all new modules on all platforms under the sun. And one of the reasons why this army is so large is how easy it is to join. Alceu Rodrigues de Freitas Juniorreminds us how to join the corps and -- to keep things interesting -- how to turn the whole thing into a game.

item.title: Organizing Perl Test Files
item.description: So you have enough tests that you have to begin to think about how to organize them? Congratulations, that's an excellent problem to have! chromatic shows us here how he goes on organizing his own tests.

item.title: Diagnosing module installation problems in Heroku
item.description: brian d foy has been playing with Heroku and Mojolicious. When things go well,they go very well. But what about when they go not as well? brian offers some tricks to debug things effectively.

item.title: Profiling in Production
item.description: Profiling software in production can sometimes feel like checking the oil level of cars on the highway. Rafael Garcia-Suarez shows us how Booking.com does it without any roadkill fatalities.

item.title: Bitcoin Is Now Supported in Encode::Base58::GMP
item.description: Dabbling in e-conomy? Good news: John Wang releases a new version of Encode::Base58::GMP that supports Bitcoin.

item.title: Raspberry Pi Modules and GUI App Released
item.description: What is niftier than a Raspberry Pi with Perl? A Raspberry Pi with Perl and(thanks to Mark Dootson) all the Wx/WxWidgets bindings, to provide nifty GUIs to your yummy Raspberry projects.

item.title: After the #masakism workshop
item.description: How Carl Masak led a bunch of people in the subway through Github while writing Perl and creating clickable maps.

item.title: 2013Q2 Grant Proposals
item.description: The Perl Foundation has four grant proposals for this quarter, dealing with conference tools,rpms, web frameworks and pinto. Go, have a look, and don't be shy to leave comments.

item.title: Interview with Gabor; Moose Classes at YAPC::NA 2013
item.description: Dave Rolsky, as interviewed by Gabor Szabo.

item.title: Interview with Tadeusz Sosnierz
item.description: Gabor Szabo's interview with Tadeusz Sosnierz (aka tadzik),the developer of the Perl 6 Pod Parser and Panda, the Perl 6 module installer.

item.title: Polish Perl Workshop 2013
item.description: May 25-26, 2013, Warsaw, Poland

item.title: YAPC::NA 2013
item.description: June 3-5, 2013, Austin, Texas, USA

item.title: YAPC::EU 2013
item.description: August 12-14, 2013, Kiev, Ukraine

item.title: YAPC::Asia Tokyo
item.description: September 19-21, 2013, Keio University Hiyoshi Campus, Tokyo, Japan
